intro: Welcome to section-two! Now our data is being loaded from a json-file. We're not using a database for simplicity's sake.

examples.title: Example 1: ngRepeat
paragraphs: Suppose we've got a couple of sections with very similar structures. This is a perfect use-case for ngRepeat.
Maybe, for instance, we're displaying photos, and we want info about the subjects of the photos to show up.
First, let's take a look at the JSON that we're working with.

images.title: Elephant
images.desc: This is an elephant. Elephants are cool.
Here I've left off the title attribute. Note that this is not a disaster. It makes things look a bit inconsistent, but it does not break anything.

examples.title: Example 2: Angular is Nice to Us
paragraphs: Yay for ngRepeat! Guess what? We're not just using ngRepeat for the photos--we're actually using it for these examples as well. Note how forgiving it is--this example doesn't have an images property at all, and yet there's no problem in rendering it.
The next example demonstrates the same concept, but with images instead of paragraphs.

examples.title: Example 4: So What's that Input Box up there for Anyway?
paragraphs: In AngularJS, it's very easy to sort through displayed data. Wherever you have your ng-repeat='example in examples' statement, for some examples array, add a pipe character with your filter requirements.
